awd_titl_txt: Investigating Effective Methods that Adults Use to Improve Children's Math Achievement in Informal Learning Environments: A Meta Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is designed to explore how adults, including parents and childcare providers, can help children better learn mathematics in informal settings. To do so, this research study will conduct a meta-analysis of mathematics teaching strategies used in informal learning environments, such as museums, libraries, and the home. A meta-analysis examines published research data, paying close attention to differences in findings, and uses statistics to analyze the findings across different studies.  This meta-analysis will summarize the relevant research about mathematics teaching that has been published since 1980, focusing on children in preschool to the end of third grade. It will also focus on mathematics learning topics of numbers and operations, algebra, geometry, measurement, and data analysis. The researchers will include data from peer-reviewed research, conference proposals, reports, and dissertations. In choosing which research studies should be included in their analysis, the researchers will consider the specific teaching strategies used, the participants in the study, and the training that the adults received. The project intends use their analysis to show what effective mathematics teaching looks like in informal learning environments.  This information can provide insights about best mathematics teaching practices for young children in informal learning environments. In this way, it can benefit mathematics education by informing the decision-making of researchers, practitioners, parents, childcare providers, teacher educators. 

After a thorough review of the literature and collection of relevant studies, the researchers will code each contributing study for methodological, participant, and intervention characteristics, study quality, and type of dependent measure. The researchers will also double code studies to establish inter-rater agreement to ensure consistency in coding procedures across reviewers. A random-effects meta-regression will then be used to synthesize standardized mean difference effect sizes to determine an overall average effect and evaluate coded moderators that may account for variability in the observed effects. Cluster robust variance estimation will be used to account for dependence between effect sizes collected from the same study. This project has the potential to make a unique contribution to the field by (a) responding to a recent upward trend of empirical research on mathematics interventions in informal learning environments; (b) reporting on the current quality of evidence of intervention studies as a means to improve future research studies in this area; (c) broadening stakeholders’ knowledge base regarding training parents and childcare providers to implement effective mathematics interventions; and (d) implementing a rigorous research plan and meta-analytic techniques.  This project is jointly funded by the Education and Human Resource Core Research (ECR) Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Introduction. Several studies have reported that early math development is associated with later math achievement in school. A recent meta-analysis also reported a positive and significant relation between activities conducted in the home math environment and children’s overall math achievement. These positive relations between early math development, home learning opportunities, and later math achievement highlight the importance of identifying effective math interventions that caregivers (e.g., parents, grandparents, other adults in primary caregiver roles) can implement in informal learning environments.

Purpose of the Meta-Analysis. Given the results of previous research and the recent focus on informal learning environments (e.g., the home, libraries, museums), we conducted a meta-analysis. A meta-analysis statistically combines results from several studies to identify an average treatment effect of interventions with common characteristics. The goal of this meta-analysis was to determine the average treatment effect of early math interventions implemented by caregivers with their young children, as well as to identify moderators of the overall effect. Finally, we determined the study reporting quality of included studies. The findings of this meta-analysis have the capacity to inform future research and practice focused on supporting families to providing early math learning opportunities for children.

Main Project Activities. We conducted a comprehensive literature search that included searching electronic databases and journal table of contents, contacting relevant researchers, posting on listservs, and conducting forward and backward citation searches. In total, we captured and screened 7,245 abstracts; from those abstracts, we reviewed the full texts of 373 studies. To be included, interventions must have been implemented by caregivers with children between the ages of 3.0 years and 9.0 years old and conducted in informal learning environments. Studies must also have administered at least one math achievement outcome measure, used an experimental or quasi-experimental group design, and reported information to calculate effect sizes. Twenty-five studies met inclusion criteria for our main meta-analysis (Nelson et al., 2024). We coded the included studies for nearly 200 variables to capture information about study information, participant demographics, intervention characteristics and content, outcome measures, and study quality. To account for dependent effect sizes, we conducted multilevel meta-analyses with robust variance estimation. We used a random effects meta-analysis and calculated effects as Hedge’s g for each study.

Meta-Analysis Outcomes. Across the 25 studies of early math interventions conducted in informal learning environments with parents and their children, 83 effect sizes yielded a statistically significant summary effect (g = 0.26, 95% CI [0.07, 0.45) on children’s math achievement. Significant moderators of the treatment effect included the intensity of parent training and type of outcome measure. There were larger average effects for interventions with parent training that included follow-up support compared to training alone or no training at all, and for outcomes that were comprehensive early numeracy measures compared to other types of outcomes. Our analysis of study reporting quality indicated that studies met 58.0% of reporting quality indicators, and that quality of reporting has improved in recent years.

Intellectual Merit. The intellectual merit of this project focuses on reporting the effects and important features of math interventions implemented in informal learning environments to various outlets (i.e., peer-reviewed journals, informational brochures for parents). By synthesizing best practices from research to provide a review of studies on math interventions implemented in informal learning environments, this meta-analysis informs relevant educational stakeholders. The intellectual merit of this project is that we identify what works for improving children’s math outcomes in informal learning settings.

 Broader Impacts: The results from this meta-analysis have the potential to impact educational stakeholders (e.g., community organization, home service providers), families and young children more broadly. The results indicate that when caregivers are provided with training and follow-up support to provide early learning opportunities, they can positively impact children’s math achievement. The results indicate that interventions do not have to be intensive to be effective and interventions that use common materials (e.g., storybooks, board games) were effective. Thus, the results of this meta-analysis have the potential to positively benefit society though enhancing the types of caregiver training and supports that researchers and other educational stakeholders provide families to improve early math learning opportunities for children.

Project Outputs: Outputs of this award include research and translational research products. Results from our meta-analysis are published in a peer-reviewed journal (Nelson et al., 2024), and the results of a follow up systematic review focused on the integration of literacy within informal early math interventions (Carter et al., 2024) are published in a peer-reviewed journal. Two other manuscripts are under review at peer-reviewed journals. Other outcomes include conference presentations, a webinar for home-visiting staff, and open access practitioner brief reports. Other key outcomes from this project include providing training opportunities in conducting meta-analyses for graduate and undergraduate students and providing researchers with open access coding manuals and data sets to use in future research studies.


Last Modified: 02/14/2024
Modified by: Gena Nelson
